name: Mushrooms of the United States Quiz | Sci / Tech | 10 Questions

questions.text: You find a large mushroom on a lawn. It has green spores. It is most likely to be in the genus...
questions.explanation:
Chlorophyllum.

	Chlorophyllum molybdites is often known as the 'green-gilled Lepiota', but it isn't a Lepiota. It's poisonous to most people and has an odd, rubbery texture. It's the only common US mushroom with a green spore print.

questions.text: Mushrooms of this genus typically have stems that snap like a piece of chalk when bent.
questions.explanation:
Russula.

	Some are edible. Many have a very hot, peppery taste.

questions.text: Which of the following genera typically is *not* mycorrhizal or associated with specific trees?
questions.explanation:
Armillariella.

	Armillariella, the honey mushroom, will grow almost anywhere that there is wood.

questions.text: Which of the following genera does not have gills?
questions.explanation:
Boletus.

	Boletes have a porous, spongy underside rather than gills.

questions.text: One interesting edible mushroom in this genus is named for its blue color.
questions.explanation:
Clitocybe.

	That mushroom is the blewit, Clitocybe nuda. It's a tasty edible. Most Clitocybes are not edible.

questions.text: The matsutake, prized by Japanese gourmets, is a member of what genus?
questions.explanation:
Armillaria.

	This mushroom is found in certain brushy habitats of the Pacific Northwest. In Japan, one specimen can sell for over $100.00!

questions.text: Mushrooms of this genus need to be eaten quickly after being picked, or they will 'self-destruct'.
questions.explanation:
Coprinus.

	They break down into black goo. Yuck. Common members of this genus include the shaggy mane, inky cap and mica cap.

questions.text: The genus name of this group of mushrooms refer to the cobwebby veil found in young specimens.
questions.explanation:
Cortinarius.

	The veil often leaves some remnants on the cap.

questions.text: One very common mushroom in this genus glows in the dark.
questions.explanation:
Omphalotus.

	The jack-o-lantern mushroom, sometimes mistaken for a chanterelle! It's poisonous, and some Eastern specimens are said to be hallucinogenic.

questions.text: The 'destroying angel', 'fly agaric' and 'death cap' are all members of what infamous genus?
questions.explanation:
Amanita.

	These are all poisonous to some degree.
